traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ByteReader
traits.docstring:
ByteReader is the interface that wraps the read_byte method.

 read_byte reads and returns the next byte from the input or
 any error encountered. If read_byte returns an error, no input
 byte was consumed, and the returned byte value is undefined.

 read_byte provides an efficient interface for byte-at-time
 processing. A [Reader] that does not implement  ByteReader
 can be wrapped using bufio.NewReader to add this method.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ByteScanner
traits.docstring:
ByteScanner is the interface that adds the unread_byte method to the
 basic read_byte method.

 unread_byte causes the next call to read_byte to return the last byte read.
 If the last operation was not a successful call to read_byte, unread_byte may
 return an error, unread the last byte read (or the byte prior to the
 last-unread byte), or (in implementations that support the [Seeker] interface)
 seek to one byte before the current offset.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ByteWriter
traits.docstring: ByteWriter is the interface that wraps the write_byte method.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.Closer
traits.docstring:
Closer is the interface that wraps the basic Close method.

 The behavior of Close after the first call is undefined.
 Specific implementations may document their own behavior.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReadCloser
traits.docstring: ReadCloser is the interface that groups the basic Read and Close methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReadSeekCloser
traits.docstring:
ReadSeekCloser is the interface that groups the basic Read, Seek and Close
 methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReadSeeker
traits.docstring: ReadSeeker is the interface that groups the basic Read and Seek methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReadWriteCloser
traits.docstring: ReadWriteCloser is the interface that groups the basic Read, Write and Close methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReadWriteSeeker
traits.docstring: ReadWriteSeeker is the interface that groups the basic Read, Write and Seek methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReadWriter
traits.docstring: ReadWriter is the interface that groups the basic Read and Write methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.Reader
traits.docstring:
Reader is the interface that wraps the basic Read method.

 Read reads up to len(p) bytes into p. It returns the number of bytes
 read (0 <= n <= len(p)) and any error encountered. Even if Read
 returns n < len(p), it may use all of p as scratch space during the call.
 If some data is available but not len(p) bytes, Read conventionally
 returns what is available instead of waiting for more.

 When Read encounters an error or end-of-file condition after
 successfully reading n > 0 bytes, it returns the number of
 bytes read. It may return the (non-None) error from the same call
 or return the error (and n == 0) from a subsequent call.
 An instance of this general case is that a Reader returning
 a non-zero number of bytes at the end of the input stream may
 return either err == eof or err == None. The next Read should
 return 0, eof.

 Callers should always process the n > 0 bytes returned before
 considering the error err. Doing so correctly handles I/O errors
 that happen after reading some bytes and also both of the
 allowed eof behaviors.

 If len(p) == 0, Read should always return n == 0. It may return a
 non-None error if some error condition is known, such as eof.

 Implementations of Read are discouraged from returning a
 zero byte count with a None error, except when len(p) == 0.
 Callers should treat a return of 0 and None as indicating that
 nothing happened; in particular it does not indicate eof.

 Implementations must not retain p.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReaderAt
traits.docstring:
ReaderAt is the interface that wraps the basic read_at method.

 read_at reads len(p) bytes into p starting at offset off in the
 underlying input source. It returns the number of bytes
 read (0 <= n <= len(p)) and any error encountered.

 When read_at returns n < len(p), it returns a non-None error
 explaining why more bytes were not returned. In this respect,
 read_at is stricter than Read.

 Even if read_at returns n < len(p), it may use all of p as scratch
 space during the call. If some data is available but not len(p) bytes,
 read_at blocks until either all the data is available or an error occurs.
 In this respect read_at is different from Read.

 If the n = len(p) bytes returned by read_at are at the end of the
 input source, read_at may return either err == eof or err == None.

 If read_at is reading from an input source with a seek offset,
 read_at should not affect nor be affected by the underlying
 seek offset.

 Clients of read_at can execute parallel read_at calls on the
 same input source.

 Implementations must not retain p.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.ReaderFrom
traits.docstring:
ReaderFrom is the interface that wraps the read_from method.

 read_from reads data from r until eof or error.
 The return value n is the number of bytes read.
 Any error except eof encountered during the read is also returned.

 The [copy] function uses [ReaderFrom] if available.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.Seeker
traits.docstring:
Seeker is the interface that wraps the basic Seek method.

 Seek sets the offset for the next Read or Write to offset,
 interpreted according to whence:
 [SeekStart] means relative to the start of the file,
 [SeekCurrent] means relative to the current offset, and
 [SeekEnd] means relative to the end
 (for example, offset = -2 specifies the penultimate byte of the file).
 Seek returns the new offset relative to the start of the
 file or an error, if any.

 Seeking to an offset before the start of the file is an error.
 Seeking to any positive offset may be allowed, but if the new offset exceeds
 the size of the underlying object the behavior of subsequent I/O operations
 is implementation-dependent.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.WriteCloser
traits.docstring: WriteCloser is the interface that groups the basic Write and Close methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.WriteSeeker
traits.docstring: WriteSeeker is the interface that groups the basic Write and Seek methods.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.Writer
traits.docstring:
Writer is the interface that wraps the basic Write method.

 Write writes len(p) bytes from p to the underlying data stream.
 It returns the number of bytes written from p (0 <= n <= len(p))
 and any error encountered that caused the write to stop early.
 Write must return a non-None error if it returns n < len(p).
 Write must not modify the slice data, even temporarily.

 Implementations must not retain p.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.WriterAt
traits.docstring:
WriterAt is the interface that wraps the basic write_at method.

 write_at writes len(p) bytes from p to the underlying data stream
 at offset off. It returns the number of bytes written from p (0 <= n <= len(p))
 and any error encountered that caused the write to stop early.
 write_at must return a non-None error if it returns n < len(p).

 If write_at is writing to a destination with a seek offset,
 write_at should not affect nor be affected by the underlying
 seek offset.

 Clients of write_at can execute parallel write_at calls on the same
 destination if the ranges do not overlap.

 Implementations must not retain p.

traits.name: @gmlewis/io.WriterTo
traits.docstring:
WriterTo is the interface that wraps the write_to method.

 write_to writes data to w until there's no more data to write or
 when an error occurs. The return value n is the number of bytes
 written. Any error encountered during the write is also returned.

 The copy function uses WriterTo if available.

methods.name: from_string
methods.docstring:
`Buffer::from_string` converts the MoonBit UTF-16 String to UTF-8
 and creates a Buffer from the bytes.

methods.name: new
methods.docstring:
Buffer::new creates a new empty Buffer with an optional size hint.
 The size hint is used to preallocate memory for the buffer, which can
 improve performance when the size of the data to be written is known in advance.

methods.name: substring
methods.signature: fn Buffer::substring(self : Buffer, start~ : Int = .., end~ : Int = ..) -> String

methods.name: write_string
methods.docstring:
`write_string` converts the MoonBit UTF-16 String to UTF-8 and
 writes the bytes to the buffer.

methods.name: read
methods.signature: fn read(self : Buffer, buf : Slice[Byte]) -> (Int, IOError?)

methods.name: write
methods.signature: fn write(self : Buffer, buf : Slice[Byte]) -> (Int, IOError?)

methods.name: op_equal
methods.signature: fn op_equal(self : Buffer, other : Buffer) -> Bool

methods.name: write
methods.docstring:
Discard implements ReaderFrom as an optimization so copy to
 io.Discard can avoid doing unnecessary work.
 let _ : &ReaderFrom = discard
methods.signature: fn write(_self : Discard, p : Slice[Byte]) -> (Int, IOError?)

types.name: IOError
types.docstring: An IOError can be tested with equality checks.

methods.name: op_equal
methods.docstring: automatically derived

methods.name: output
methods.docstring: automatically derived

types.name: LimitedReader
types.docstring:
A LimitedReader reads from R but limits the amount of
 data returned to just N bytes. Each call to Read
 updates N to reflect the new amount remaining.
 Read returns eof when N <= 0 or when the underlying R returns eof.

methods.name: new
methods.docstring:
LimitedReader::new returns a Reader that reads from r
 but stops with eof after n bytes.
 The underlying implementation is a LimitedReader.

methods.name: new
methods.docstring:
NopCloser::new returns a [ReadCloser] with a no-op Close method wrapping
 the provided [Reader] r.
 If r implements [WriterTo], the returned [ReadCloser] will implement [WriterTo]
 by forwarding calls to r.

types.name: OffsetWriter
types.docstring: An OffsetWriter maps writes at offset base to offset base+off in the underlying writer.

methods.name: new
methods.docstring:
OffsetWriter::new returns an [OffsetWriter] that writes to w
 starting at offset off.

types.name: SectionReader
types.docstring:
SectionReader implements Read, Seek, and read_at on a section
 of an underlying [ReaderAt].

methods.name: new
methods.docstring:
SectionReader::new returns a [SectionReader] that reads from r
 starting at offset off and stops with eof after n bytes.
methods.signature: fn SectionReader::new(r : ReaderAt, off : Int64, n : Int64) -> SectionReader

types.name: Slice
types.docstring:
A `Slice` is a slice of an `Array`.

 A separate Slice type was needed because of this issue:
 https://github.com/moonbitlang/core/issues/1063

 This struct is based on MoonBit's "ArrayView" implementation here:
 https://github.com/moonbitlang/core/blob/main/builtin/arrayview.mbt
 which has the following copyright:

 Copyright 2024 International Digital Economy Academy

 Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
 you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
 You may obtain a copy of the License at

     http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
 distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
 WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
 See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
 limitations under the License.

methods.name: append
methods.docstring:
append appends `s` to the end of the slice, reallocating the underlying
 array if necessary, then returns the new slice.

methods.name: cap
methods.docstring: cap returns the total capacity of the slice regardless of the current length.

methods.name: fold
methods.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].fold(init=0, fn { sum, elem => sum + elem })
 sum // 15
 ```
methods.signature: fn Slice::fold[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (B, A) -> B) -> B

methods.name: foldi
methods.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules with index.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].foldi(init=0, fn { index, sum, elem => sum + index })
 sum // 10
 ```
methods.signature: fn Slice::foldi[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (Int, B, A) -> B) -> B

methods.name: length
methods.docstring: length returns the length of the slice.

methods.name: new
methods.signature: fn Slice::new[T](buf : Array[T], start~ : Int = .., end? : Int) -> Slice[T]

methods.name: op_as_view
methods.signature: fn Slice::op_as_view[T](self : Slice[T], start~ : Int = .., end? : Int) -> Slice[T]

methods.name: op_set
methods.signature: fn Slice::op_set[T](self : Slice[T], index : Int, value : T) -> Unit

methods.name: push
methods.docstring:
push appends `e` to the end of the slice, reallocating the underlying
 array if necessary, then returns the new slice.

methods.name: rev_fold
methods.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules in reversed turn.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].rev_fold(init=0, fn { sum, elem => sum + elem })
 sum // 15
 ```
methods.signature: fn Slice::rev_fold[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (B, A) -> B) -> B

methods.name: rev_foldi
methods.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules in reversed turn with index.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].rev_foldi(~init=0, fn { index, sum, elem => sum + index })
 sum // 10
 ```
methods.signature: fn Slice::rev_foldi[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (Int, B, A) -> B) -> B

methods.name: swap
methods.signature: fn Slice::swap[T](self : Slice[T], i : Int, j : Int) -> Unit

methods.name: to_bytes
methods.docstring: to_bytes returns slice as Bytes.

methods.name: op_equal
methods.docstring: Compares two slices for equality.
methods.signature: fn op_equal[T : Eq](self : Slice[T], other : Slice[T]) -> Bool

methods.name: new
methods.docstring:
TeeReader::new returns a [Reader] that writes to w what it reads from r.
 All reads from r performed through it are matched with
 corresponding writes to w. There is no internal buffering -
 the write must complete before the read completes.
 Any error encountered while writing is reported as a read error.

types.name: Whence

values.name: append
values.docstring:
append appends `s` to the end of the slice, reallocating the underlying
 array if necessary, then returns the new slice.
values.signature: fn append[T](self : Slice[T], s : Slice[T]) -> Slice[T]

values.name: as_array_view
values.signature: fn as_array_view[T](self : Slice[T]) -> ArrayView[T]

values.name: cap
values.docstring: cap returns the total capacity of the slice regardless of the current length.
values.signature: fn cap[T](self : Slice[T]) -> Int

values.name: copy
values.docstring:
copy copies from src to dst until either eof is reached
 on src or an error occurs. It returns the number of bytes
 copied and the first error encountered while copying, if any.

 A successful copy returns err == None, not err == eof.
 Because copy is defined to read from src until eof, it does
 not treat an eof from Read as an error to be reported.

 If src implements [WriterTo],
 the copy is implemented by calling src.write_to(dst).
 Otherwise, if dst implements [ReaderFrom],
 the copy is implemented by calling dst.read_from(src).
values.signature: fn copy(dst : Writer, src : Reader) -> (Int64, IOError?)

values.name: copy_buffer
values.docstring:
copy_buffer is identical to copy except that it stages through the
 provided buffer (if one is required) rather than allocating a
 temporary one. If buf is None, one is allocated; otherwise if it has
 zero length, copy_buffer panics.

 If either src implements [WriterTo] or dst implements [ReaderFrom],
 buf will not be used to perform the copy.
values.signature: fn copy_buffer(dst : Writer, src : Reader, buf : Slice[Byte]?) -> (Int64, IOError?)

values.name: copy_json
values.docstring:
copy_json copies bytes from a source reader until a valid JSON value is completed.
 It returns the Json value, the number of bytes copied, and any error that occurred during the process.
values.signature: fn copy_json(src : ByteReader) -> (Json, Int64, IOError?)

values.name: copy_n
values.docstring:
copy_n copies n bytes (or until an error) from src to dst.
 It returns the number of bytes copied and the earliest
 error encountered while copying.
 On return, written == n if and only if err == None.

 If dst implements [ReaderFrom], the copy is implemented using it.
values.signature: fn copy_n(dst : Writer, src : Reader, n : Int64) -> (Int64, IOError?)

values.name: copy_size
values.docstring:
copy_size copies a specified number of bytes from a source reader to a
 destination writer. It returns the number of bytes copied and any error
 that occurred during the process.
values.signature: fn copy_size(dst : Writer, src : ByteReader, size : Int64) -> (Int64, IOError?)

values.name: copy_until
values.docstring:
copy_until copies bytes from a source reader to a destination writer
 until a specified byte is encountered. It returns the number of bytes
 copied and any error that occurred during the process.
values.signature: fn copy_until(dst : Writer, src : ByteReader, until : Byte) -> (Int64, IOError?)

values.name: discard
values.docstring:
discard is a [Writer] on which all Write calls succeed
 without doing anything.
values.signature: let discard : Discard

values.name: each
values.signature: fn each[T](self : Slice[T], f : (T) -> Unit) -> Unit

values.name: eof
values.docstring:
eof is the error returned by Read when no more input is available.
 (Read must return eof itself, not an error wrapping eof,
 because callers will test for eof using ==.)
 Functions should return eof only to signal a graceful end of input.
 If the eof occurs unexpectedly in a structured data stream,
 the appropriate error is either [err_unexpected_eof] or some other error
 giving more detail.
values.signature: let eof : IOError

values.name: err_invalid_write
values.docstring: err_invalid_write means that a write returned an impossible count.
values.signature: let err_invalid_write : IOError

values.name: err_no_progress
values.docstring:
err_no_progress is returned by some clients of a [Reader] when
 many calls to Read have failed to return any data or error,
 usually the sign of a broken [Reader] implementation.
values.signature: let err_no_progress : IOError

values.name: err_offset
values.signature: let err_offset : IOError

values.name: err_short_buffer
values.docstring: err_short_buffer means that a read required a longer buffer than was provided.
values.signature: let err_short_buffer : IOError

values.name: err_short_write
values.docstring:
err_short_write means that a write accepted fewer bytes than requested
 but failed to return an explicit error.
values.signature: let err_short_write : IOError

values.name: err_unexpected_eof
values.docstring:
err_unexpected_eof means that eof was encountered in the
 middle of reading a fixed-size block or data structure.
values.signature: let err_unexpected_eof : IOError

values.name: err_whence
values.signature: let err_whence : IOError

values.name: fold
values.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].fold(init=0, fn { sum, elem => sum + elem })
 sum // 15
 ```
values.signature: fn fold[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (B, A) -> B) -> B

values.name: foldi
values.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules with index.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].foldi(init=0, fn { index, sum, elem => sum + index })
 sum // 10
 ```
values.signature: fn foldi[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (Int, B, A) -> B) -> B

values.name: iter
values.signature: fn iter[A](self : Slice[A]) -> Iter[A]

values.name: iter2
values.signature: fn iter2[A](self : Slice[A]) -> Iter2[Int, A]

values.name: length
values.signature: fn length(self : Buffer) -> Int

values.name: op_as_view
values.signature: fn op_as_view[T](self : Slice[T], start~ : Int = .., end? : Int) -> Slice[T]

values.name: op_get
values.signature: fn op_get[T](self : Slice[T], index : Int) -> T

values.name: op_set
values.signature: fn op_set[T](self : Slice[T], index : Int, value : T) -> Unit

values.name: push
values.docstring:
push appends `e` to the end of the slice, reallocating the underlying
 array if necessary, then returns the new slice.
values.signature: fn push[T](self : Slice[T], e : T) -> Slice[T]

values.name: read_all
values.docstring:
read_all reads from r until an error or eof and returns the data it read.
 A successful call returns err == None, not err == eof. Because read_all is
 defined to read from src until eof, it does not treat an eof from Read
 as an error to be reported.
values.signature: fn read_all(r : Reader) -> (Slice[Byte], IOError?)

values.name: read_from
values.signature: fn read_from(self : Buffer, r : Reader) -> (Int64, IOError?)

values.name: read_full
values.docstring:
read_full reads exactly len(buf) bytes from r into buf.
 It returns the number of bytes copied and an error if fewer bytes were read.
 The error is eof only if no bytes were read.
 If an eof happens after reading some but not all the bytes,
 read_full returns [err_unexpected_eof].
 On return, n == len(buf) if and only if err == None.
 If r returns an error having read at least len(buf) bytes, the error is dropped.
values.signature: fn read_full(r : Reader, buf : Slice[Byte]) -> (Int, IOError?)

values.name: reset
values.signature: fn reset(self : Buffer, size_hint~ : Int = ..) -> Unit

values.name: rev_fold
values.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules in reversed turn.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].rev_fold(init=0, fn { sum, elem => sum + elem })
 sum // 15
 ```
values.signature: fn rev_fold[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (B, A) -> B) -> B

values.name: rev_foldi
values.docstring:
Fold out values from an Slice according to certain rules in reversed turn with index.

 # Example
 ```
 let sum = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5][:].rev_foldi(~init=0, fn { index, sum, elem => sum + index })
 sum // 10
 ```
values.signature: fn rev_foldi[A, B](self : Slice[A], init~ : B, f : (Int, B, A) -> B) -> B

values.name: rev_inplace
values.signature: fn rev_inplace[T](self : Slice[T]) -> Unit

values.name: substring
values.signature: fn substring(self : Buffer, start~ : Int = .., end~ : Int = ..) -> String

values.name: swap
values.signature: fn swap[T](self : Slice[T], i : Int, j : Int) -> Unit

values.name: to_bytes
values.signature: fn to_bytes(self : Buffer) -> Bytes

values.name: to_slice
values.signature: fn to_slice(self : Buffer) -> Slice[Byte]

values.name: write_byte
values.signature: fn write_byte(self : Buffer, b : Byte) -> (Int, IOError?)

values.name: write_bytes
values.signature: fn write_bytes(self : Buffer, buf : Bytes) -> (Int, IOError?)

values.name: write_string
values.docstring:
`write_string` converts the MoonBit UTF-16 String to UTF-8 and
 writes the bytes to the buffer.
values.signature: fn write_string(self : Buffer, s : String) -> (Int, IOError?)
